"**I Can 't Make You Love Me**" is a song written by [Mike
Reid](/wiki/Mike_Reid_\(singer\) "Mike Reid \(singer\)") and [Allen
Shamblin](/wiki/Allen_Shamblin "Allen Shamblin") and recorded by American
singer [Bonnie Raitt](/wiki/Bonnie_Raitt "Bonnie Raitt") for her eleventh
studio album _[Luck of the Draw](/wiki/Luck_of_the_Draw_\(album\) "Luck of the
Draw \(album\)")_ (1991). Released as the album's third single in 1991, "I
Can't Make You Love Me" became one of Raitt's most successful singles,
reaching the top-twenty on the [_Billboard_ Hot 100](/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100
"Billboard Hot 100") chart and the top-ten on the [Adult
Contemporary](/wiki/Adult_Contemporary "Adult Contemporary").

In August 2000, _[Mojo](/wiki/Mojo_\(magazine\) "Mojo \(magazine\)")_ magazine
voted "I Can't Make You Love Me" the eighth best track on its The 100 Greatest
Songs of All Time list.[1] The song is ranked at number 339 on the _[Rolling
Stone](/wiki/Rolling_Stone "Rolling Stone")_ magazine's list of [The 500
Greatest Songs of All
Time](/wiki/Rolling_Stone%27s_500_Greatest_Songs_of_All_Time "Rolling Stone's
500 Greatest Songs of All Time").[2] On 27 November 2016, the [Grammy Hall of
Fame](/wiki/Grammy_Hall_of_Fame "Grammy Hall of Fame") announced its
induction, along with that of another 24 songs.[3]

## Writing and
recording[[edit](/w/index.php?title=I_Can%27t_Make_You_Love_Me&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Writing and recording")]

"I Can’t Make You Love Me" was written by Nashville writers [Mike
Reid](/wiki/Mike_Reid_\(singer\) "Mike Reid \(singer\)") and [Allen
Shamblin](/wiki/Allen_Shamblin "Allen Shamblin"), who were well-noted for
their successes in the country music arena. The song was rewritten many times
before being finalized, months later. "We wrote, most every week, in Mike’s
basement," Shamblin told Peter Cooper in an interview with the [Nashville
Tennessean](/wiki/Nashville_Tennessean "Nashville Tennessean"). "And we’d
worked on this song for more than six months. One day, he said, ‘Come up to
the living room,’ where his piano was. He sat down and started playing this
melody, and it was one of the most moving pieces of music I’d heard. I mean,
it hit me in a hard way... Instantly, I knew it was the best thing I’d ever
been a part of."[4] Reid and Shamblin were both [country
music](/wiki/Country_music "Country music") songwriters, who according to some
accounts originally wrote the song as a fast,
[bluegrass](/wiki/Bluegrass_music "Bluegrass music") number. Upon slowing down
the tempo considerably, they realized the song gained considerable power and
thought about giving the song to one of three artists: [Bonnie
Raitt](/wiki/Bonnie_Raitt "Bonnie Raitt"), [Bette Midler](/wiki/Bette_Midler
"Bette Midler") or [Linda Ronstadt](/wiki/Linda_Ronstadt "Linda Ronstadt").
Eventually, the song made its way to [Bonnie Raitt](/wiki/Bonnie_Raitt "Bonnie
Raitt"), who recorded the track for her eleventh studio album, "[Luck of the
Draw](/wiki/Luck_of_the_Draw_\(album\) "Luck of the Draw \(album\)")" (1991).
Raitt co-produced the song with [Don Was](/wiki/Don_Was "Don Was"), while
[Bruce Hornsby](/wiki/Bruce_Hornsby "Bruce Hornsby") provided a piano
accompaniment.[5]

## Composition and
inspiration[[edit](/w/index.php?title=I_Can%27t_Make_You_Love_Me&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Composition and inspiration")]

"I Can't Make You Love Me" was composed in the [key](/wiki/Key_\(music\) "Key
\(music\)") of [Bb major](/wiki/Bb_major "Bb major"), with a moderate slow
tempo of 72 [beats per minute](/wiki/Beats_per_minute "Beats per minute").
Raitt's vocal range on the song spans from the low-note of F3 to the high-note
of Bb4.[6] The idea for the song came to Reid while reading an article about a
man arrested for getting drunk and shooting at his girlfriend's car. The judge
asked him if he had learned anything, to which he replied, "I learned, Your
Honor, that you can't make a woman love you if she don't."[7] Raitt recorded
the vocal in just one take in the studio, later saying that it was so sad a
song that she could not recapture the emotion: "We'd try to do it again and I
just said, 'You know, this ain't going to happen.'"[8]

A pensive [ballad](/wiki/Ballad "Ballad"), "I Can't Make You Love Me" was
recorded against a quiet [electric piano](/wiki/Electric_piano "Electric
piano")-based arrangement, with prominent [piano](/wiki/Piano "Piano") fills
and interpolations supplied by [Bruce Hornsby](/wiki/Bruce_Hornsby "Bruce
Hornsby"). The singer depicts a now one-sided romantic relationship about to
end in soft but brutally honest terms: "Turn down the lights, turn down the
bed/Turn down these voices inside my head/Lay down with me, tell me no
lies/Just hold me close, don't patronize... don't patronize me/'Cause I can't
make you love me if you don't/You can't make your heart feel something that it
won't," she sings.[9]

## Critical reception and
accolades[[edit](/w/index.php?title=I_Can%27t_Make_You_Love_Me&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Critical reception and accolades")]

"I Can't Make You Love Me" received acclaim from [music
critics](/wiki/Music_critics "Music critics"). [Stephen Thomas
Erlewine](/wiki/Stephen_Thomas_Erlewine "Stephen Thomas Erlewine") of
[AllMusic](/wiki/AllMusic "AllMusic") praised the track, calling it a "strong
song" and picking it as one of the album's best tracks.[10] Steve Hochman of
_[Los Angeles Times](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Times "Los Angeles Times")_ hailed the
song as one of Raitt's most elegant tracks.[11] Elysa Gardner wrote for
_[Rolling Stone](/wiki/Rolling_Stone "Rolling Stone")_ that "Raitt's
gorgeously understated rendering of 'I Can't Make You Love Me,' in which
sentiments such as 'I will lay down my heart and I'll feel the power/But you
won't' are delivered with a quiet resignation that's worth a hundred glissandi
in emotional weight."[12]

"I Can't Make You Love Me" entered many lists of the greatest songs of all
time. In 2000, [Mojo magazine](/wiki/Mojo_magazine "Mojo magazine") placed it
at number 8 on its "100 Greatest Songs of All Time" list.[5] The song is also
ranked #339 on the [Rolling Stone](/wiki/Rolling_Stone "Rolling Stone")
magazine's list of [The 500 Greatest Songs of All
Time](/wiki/The_500_Greatest_Songs_of_All_Time "The 500 Greatest Songs of All
Time").[2] The website "Ultimate Classic Rock" placed the song at number 24 on
their "25 Saddest Songs Ever", praising Bonnie Raitt vocals, writing that "she
sings in one of her most impassioned vocals ever. There's real ache in every
word that drips from her pained lips."[13]

The song's popularity helped solidify her remarkable late-in-career commercial
success that had begun two years before. In the time since, "I Can't Make You
Love Me" has gone on to become a pop standard and a mainstay of adult
contemporary radio formats. For Raitt, the song was notoriously difficult to
sing, due to its required vocal range, difficult phrasing and breathing, and
the emotional content involved. At the televised [Grammy Awards of
1992](/wiki/Grammy_Awards_of_1992 "Grammy Awards of 1992") Raitt performed it
in an even more austere setting than on record, with just her and Hornsby
highlighted. As she negotiated the final vocal line, she let out a big audible
and visible sigh of relief that she had successfully gotten through it. Her
live performance of the song was released on the 1994 album _Grammy 's
Greatest Moments Volume III_.[14] Raitt has continued to sing the song in all
her concert tours:

“ | I mean, 'I Can't Make You Love Me' is no picnic. I love that song, so does the audience. So it's almost a sacred moment when you share that, that depth of pain with your audience. Because they get really quiet, and I have to summon ... some other place in order to honor that space. | ”  
---|---|---  
  
## Chart
performance[[edit](/w/index.php?title=I_Can%27t_Make_You_Love_Me&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Chart performance")]

The song was a big hit for Raitt, reaching number 18 on the [_Billboard_ Hot
100](/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100 "Billboard Hot 100") and number 6 on the
[Billboard Adult Contemporary](/wiki/Adult_Contemporary_\(chart\) "Adult
Contemporary \(chart\)") chart.[15] The song placed at number 100 on the
[_Billboard_ Year-End](/wiki/Billboard_Year-End "Billboard Year-End") chart of
1992.[16] In [New Zealand](/wiki/New_Zealand "New Zealand"), the song was
Raitt's highest charting-single, reaching number 22,[17] while in
[Netherlands](/wiki/Netherlands "Netherlands"), the song charted moderately at
number 43.[18]

## Bruce Hornsby performance
use[[edit](/w/index.php?title=I_Can%27t_Make_You_Love_Me&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Bruce Hornsby performance use")]

Although Bruce Hornsby had no hand in writing the song, his piano part on it
became associated with him. [Phil Collins](/wiki/Phil_Collins "Phil Collins")
described it as instantly recognizable as Hornsby's work.[22] Hornsby's own
publicity material mentions his role on the "classic".[23]

On his own subsequent tours, Hornsby included the song in a number of his set
lists. He sometimes let a female backing singer in his band take on the
vocal.[24] Other times, he sang the song himself.[25]

English singer [George Michael](/wiki/George_Michael "George Michael") covered
"I Can't Make You Love Me" and released as a B-side of his single,
"[Older](/wiki/Older_\(George_Michael_song\) "Older \(George Michael
song\)")", which was released on 20 January 1997 as the fourth single from the
[album of the same name](/wiki/Older_\(album\) "Older \(album\)"). Michael's
version was also included on his compilation, _[Ladies& Gentlemen: The Best of
George Michael](/wiki/Ladies_%26_Gentlemen:_The_Best_of_George_Michael "Ladies
& Gentlemen: The Best of George Michael")_ (1998). "Older" and "I Can't Make
You Love Me" both reached number 3 on the [UK Singles
Chart](/wiki/UK_Singles_Chart "UK Singles Chart").

### Background and
release[[edit](/w/index.php?title=I_Can%27t_Make_You_Love_Me&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Background and release")]

After the release of his second studio album, _[Listen Without Prejudice Vol.
1](/wiki/Listen_Without_Prejudice_Vol._1 "Listen Without Prejudice Vol. 1")_
(1990), George Michael started a [legal
battle](/wiki/Panayiotou_v_Sony_Music_Entertainment_\(UK\)_Ltd "Panayiotou v
Sony Music Entertainment \(UK\) Ltd") with his label, [Sony
Music](/wiki/Sony_Music_Entertainment "Sony Music Entertainment"), declaring
his contract was financially inequitable and creatively stifling. Michael sued
Sony to end his contract, leading to a long and costly legal battle that ended
in 1995, with Michael signing to the newly launched [Dreamworks
Records](/wiki/Dreamworks_Records "Dreamworks Records") label in the United
States and [Virgin](/wiki/Virgin_Records "Virgin Records") in the rest of the
world.[26] In 1995, the singer released the song "[Jesus to a
Child](/wiki/Jesus_to_a_Child "Jesus to a Child")", which became a huge hit
worldwide, followed by "[Fastlove](/wiki/Fastlove "Fastlove")" and "[Spinning
the Wheel](/wiki/Spinning_the_Wheel "Spinning the Wheel")", which also became
successful songs from his third studio album,
_[Older](/wiki/Older_\(George_Michael_song\) "Older \(George Michael song\)")_
(1996).[27][28]

While choosing the fourth single from the album, the title track
"[Older](/wiki/Older_\(George_Michael_song\) "Older \(George Michael song\)")"
was announced as the chosen one, with an EP also titled "Older" being released
to promote the song. The EP features four tracks, including "Older", "[The
Strangest Thing](/wiki/You_Have_Been_Loved "You Have Been Loved")" (also from
the album "Older") and two covers: the famous Brazilian song
"[Desafinado](/wiki/Desafinado "Desafinado")" and [Bonnie
Raitt](/wiki/Bonnie_Raitt "Bonnie Raitt")'s "I Can't Make You Love Me",[29]
which became the official B-side of the single. Since it was released as a
B-side to "Older", "I Can't Make You Love Me" also entered the [UK Singles
Chart](/wiki/UK_Singles_Chart "UK Singles Chart") at number 3.[28]

chart.

### Background and
release[[edit](/w/index.php?title=I_Can%27t_Make_You_Love_Me&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Background and release")]

After releasing their second [cover album](/wiki/Cover_album "Cover album") in
2007, _[Motown: A Journey Through Hitsville
USA](/wiki/Motown:_A_Journey_Through_Hitsville_USA "Motown: A Journey Through
Hitsville USA")_ , which was well received by critics, but failed to produce a
successful single, the band announced plans for a new cover album, that
features cover versions of songs by "artists I don't think people would expect
us to cover," according to member [Shawn Stockman](/wiki/Shawn_Stockman "Shawn
Stockman").[30] On October 23, 2009, "I Can't Make You Love Me" was announced
as _[Love](/wiki/Love_\(Boyz_II_Men_album\) "Love \(Boyz II Men album\)")'_s
lead-single.[31] The song was later released on October 27, 2009 through
[iTunes store](/wiki/ITunes_store "ITunes store").[32] For the band members,
"We wanted to stay true to our roots, and it's a very beautiful song. And with
our sound, we gave it an [R&B](/wiki/Contemporary_R%26B "Contemporary R&B")
twist. It's always been a favorite of ours, and we hope people will fall in
love with it again."[33]

###
Reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=I_Can%27t_Make_You_Love_Me&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Reception")]

A writer for _Soul Bounce_ wrote that "The biggest surprise on this album is
the bluesy interpretation of Bonnie Rait's country hit, 'I Can't Make You Love
Me.' Starting with strong lyrics and a deep fried instrumental, the Boyz make
this song their own with their unique flow providing good contrast to a
familiar melodic line."[34] _[Los Angeles Theatre](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Theatre
"Los Angeles Theatre")_ called it an "impassioned" performance.[35] On the
charts, the song performed very modestly, reaching number 75 on the [Hot
R&B/Hip-Hop Songs](/wiki/Hot_R%26B/Hip-Hop_Songs "Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs")
chart.[36]

In 2011, English singer [Adele](/wiki/Adele "Adele") covered "I Can't Make You
Love Me" for her first [live album](/wiki/Live_album "Live album"), _[Live at
the Royal Albert Hall](/wiki/Live_at_the_Royal_Albert_Hall_\(Adele_video\)
"Live at the Royal Albert Hall \(Adele video\)")_ (2011). The song was
acclaimed by music critics, who praised Adele's delivery and vocals. The song
has charted on the [UK Singles Chart](/wiki/UK_Singles_Chart "UK Singles
Chart"), reaching the top-forty, although it was never released as a single.

### Background and live
performances[[edit](/w/index.php?title=I_Can%27t_Make_You_Love_Me&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: Background and live performances")]

In addition to receiving positive reviews from music critics, Adele's second
album _[21](/wiki/21_\(Adele_album\) "21 \(Adele album\)")_ became one of the
most successful albums of the 2010s, being the biggest selling musical release
for both 2011 and 2012 and entering the _[Guinness World
Records](/wiki/Guinness_World_Records "Guinness World Records")_. While
promoting the album and its third single, "[Set Fire to the
Rain](/wiki/Set_Fire_to_the_Rain "Set Fire to the Rain")", Adele performed on
the [iTunes Festival London 2011](/wiki/ITunes_Festival#2011 "ITunes
Festival"). On the setlist, Adele performed tracks from _21_ and a cover of "I
Can't Make You Love Me". Before performing the track, Adele stated that it was
one of her favorite songs and described it as "perfect in every way". She
added that Bonnie Raitt has a "stunning voice" and went on to compliment the
lyrics, calling them "mind-blowing".[37]

After the positive response of the _iTunes Festival_ performance, Adele
covered once again the track, during her first [live album](/wiki/Live_album
"Live album"), _[Live at the Royal Albert
Hall](/wiki/Live_at_the_Royal_Albert_Hall_\(Adele_video\) "Live at the Royal
Albert Hall \(Adele video\)")_ , recorded on 22 September 2011. She made
further comment over the song, saying, "It blows me away" and further adding
that she thought the song was "incredibly moving". Adele also commented on the
emotions the song gives her, saying, "It makes me really, really happy and
really, really devastated and depressed at the same time. It makes me think of
my fondest and best times in my life, and it makes me think of the worst as
well, and combined, probably is a recipe for disaster, but I do love this
song. It's just fucking stunning."[38]

### Critical
reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=I_Can%27t_Make_You_Love_Me&action=edit&section=18
"Edit section: Critical reception")]

While reviewing her _iTunes Festival_ performance, David Smyth of _[London
Evening Standard](/wiki/London_Evening_Standard "London Evening Standard")_
wrote that Adele sang the song "with raw expressiveness."[39] Andrew Leahey of
_[Allmusic](/wiki/Allmusic "Allmusic")_ wrote that the cover "made all the
more tender by the rarely heard frailties in Adele’s voice."[40] Donald Gibson
of _Seattle Pi_ wrote that "she breathes new life into Bonnie Raitt's 'I Can't
Make You Love Me,' with similar intimacy and conviction."[41]

While reviewing her _[Live at the Royal Albert
Hall](/wiki/Live_at_the_Royal_Albert_Hall_\(Adele_video\) "Live at the Royal
Albert Hall \(Adele video\)")_ DVD, critics lauded Adele's rendition. Andy
Gill of _[The Independent](/wiki/The_Independent "The Independent")_ called it
an "impassioned version,"[42] while Alex Young of _[Consequence of
Sound](/wiki/Consequence_of_Sound "Consequence of Sound")_ named it "heartfelt
and stunning."[43] Kit O'Toole of _[Blogcritics](/wiki/Blogcritics
"Blogcritics")_ praised her rendition, writing that it "retains its heart-
wrenching, devastating mood thanks to Adele's multi-layered voice. Hearing her
perform this song, one would imagine her as an older woman who has survived
lifelong heartaches instead of a 23-year-old."[44] Maria Schurr of
_[PopMatters](/wiki/PopMatters "PopMatters")_ lauded the covers (Raitt's "I
Can't Make You Love Me" and [Bob Dylan](/wiki/Bob_Dylan "Bob Dylan")'s "[Make
You Feel My Love](/wiki/Make_You_Feel_My_Love "Make You Feel My Love")") on
the live album, naming "the most successful," writing that "both seem deeply
heartfelt, like Adele understands, and is the only one who can make these
words that are not hers ring true."[45] Chris Willman of _[The
Wrap](/wiki/The_Wrap "The Wrap")_ called it "a classic of unrequited love that
you'd have to swear she wrote if Bonnie Raitt hadn't turned it into the
ultimate female weepie back when Adele was 2."[46]

### Chart
performance[[edit](/w/index.php?title=I_Can%27t_Make_You_Love_Me&action=edit&section=19
"Edit section: Chart performance")]

Despite not being released as a single, "I Can't Make You Love Me" debuted at
number 53 on the [UK Singles Chart](/wiki/UK_Singles_Chart "UK Singles Chart")
week of 30 September 2012.[47] It later peaked at number 37, on the following
week, 6 October 2012,[48] becoming her eighth top-forty song and first non-
single top-forty hit.

In 2014, Indian actress and singer [Priyanka Chopra](/wiki/Priyanka_Chopra
"Priyanka Chopra") recorded a version of "I Can't Make You Love Me" for her
upcoming debut studio album. Speaking about the song, Chopra said "This is one
of my favorite tracks on the album. It's my ode to a classic, a song that I
love, and one that says so much – this is for the actor in me."[51] Chopra's
version of the song incorporates [electronic dance
music](/wiki/Electronic_dance_music "Electronic dance music") (EDM) and
[electropop](/wiki/Electropop "Electropop") in its production,.[52][53] which
comes courtesy of German producer Manuel "[DJ Manian](/wiki/DJ_Manian "DJ
Manian")" Reuter. Andy Gensler from _[Billboard](/wiki/Billboard_\(magazine\)
"Billboard \(magazine\)")_ commented on how different Chopra's version was
from the original by Raitt, saying that "Chopra's more uptempo take on the
song is more likely to connect with a generation of ravers with no idea of the
song's origin"[54] The up-tempo version was demoed by American singer [Ester
Dean](/wiki/Ester_Dean "Ester Dean") at the request of Interscope Records
chairman [Jimmy Iovine](/wiki/Jimmy_Iovine "Jimmy Iovine").[54]

It was released on 22 April 2014, by [DesiHits](/wiki/DesiHits "DesiHits"), in
association with [2101 Records](/wiki/2101_Records "2101 Records") and
[Interscope Records](/wiki/Interscope_Records "Interscope Records").[55][56]
It is the third internationally released single following "[In My
City](/wiki/In_My_City "In My City")" (featuring [will.i.am](/wiki/Will.i.am
"Will.i.am")), which failed to achieve airplay in the United States,[57] and
"[Exotic](/wiki/Exotic_\(song\) "Exotic \(song\)")". In the United Kingdom, "I
Can't Make You Love Me" was originally planned to be Chopra's debut single,
but was never released.[53]

### Promotion and music
video[[edit](/w/index.php?title=I_Can%27t_Make_You_Love_Me&action=edit&section=21
"Edit section: Promotion and music video")]

Chopra's version of "I Can't Make You Love Me" was used to promote [Beats by
Dre](/wiki/Beats_by_Dre "Beats by Dre"). In a press release, it was revealed
that the song would be used in the launch of a new campaign for the popular
Beats Pill XL portable Bluetooth speaker. Chopra and her new track would be
featured in the national ad campaign, that ran nationwide from May 1 through
May 25.[58]

An accompanying [music video](/wiki/Music_video "Music video") was filmed in
[Los Angeles](/wiki/Los_Angeles "Los Angeles") in February 2014.[59] It was
conceptualised and directed by duo Jeff Nicholas and Jonathan Craven of The
Uprising Creative.[56] Actor [Milo Ventimiglia](/wiki/Milo_Ventimiglia "Milo
Ventimiglia") plays Chopra's love interest and scenes include Chopra throwing
coloured paint at Ventimiglia as part of celebrations for the Indian festival
of [Holi](/wiki/Holi "Holi"), as well as embraces between the couple and solo
scenes with Chopra.[59] According to [NDTV](/wiki/NDTV "NDTV"), the video
charts a fictional relationship that "goes from loving to hellish".[60] Behind
the scenes footage was released to [Access Hollywood](/wiki/Access_Hollywood
"Access Hollywood").[61] It premiered in [New York City](/wiki/New_York_City
"New York City") on 30 April 2014.[52] Gensler noted that the video also
contained product placement for [Nokia](/wiki/Nokia "Nokia") and Beats by Dre
speakers.[54]

### Critical
reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=I_Can%27t_Make_You_Love_Me&action=edit&section=22
"Edit section: Critical reception")]

[CNN-News18](/wiki/CNN-News18 "CNN-News18") said, "The singer certainly sounds
great, so much that it's almost unbelievable it is Priyanka Chopra. The number
is definitely foot-tapping and you're going to be hearing this one at every
restaurant and club in the days to come" and added that Chopra had "definitely
done a great job recreating the Bonnie Ratt song".[62]
